element_texts.text:
Dear Lucile- 

        Just got back to Chicago after a great time in New Orleans.  I wrote the book I had on my chest when I left New York - Now I'll have to settle down and give it another going over. Think I've got something. Cant be too sure yet.
        New Orleans was a delightful experience.  I wrote something about it for the March number of a little magazine called Double Dealer.  You'll find it at the Nash or Pagan book shop - I think.  Would send it myself if I had it.
       Anyway New Orleans got

me hard, the place, people and everything.  Some day I'll tell you more about it.  New York and Chicago are like twice closed fists.  New Orleans is an open handed place.

       Tennessee has to give up her  place here April 1st as they are tearing the building she lives in down.  She is going out with me to the little place I have at- Palos Park .  That- is only an hour out of Chicago.  Write me 19th Floor Brooks Bldg - Chicago until April 1st after that Palos Park.
          The point is that when you come out

here both of us would like to see as much of you as we can.  Will Jerry come.  The place at Palos is tiny but if you could spend some days out there we'd manage to skirmish up a room in the neighborhood.  After April 15th it should be fine in the country. And we got a fliver.
The thing I started in New Orleans may go to 3 or 4 volumes - can't tell - but it is told in Episodes and the 1st episode is a complete thing in itself.  Its a great theme - if I'm able to

really handle it.
Well I know how you feel about spring. the blood begins to dance when the sap starts up the trees.
The New Testament thing is experimental.  What I suppose I'm after is a new intensity of purse? handling.
Gee I hope you come out and old Jerry too.
Sherwood.

Dear Lucile - 

        Tell Jerry I'm off in the morning.  I'm leaving keys to my place with Elizabeth - for him.  Should be gone about 3 or 4 weeks.  Feel as though I were going to work..
       I love you both.
           Sherwood.

Dear Lucile - how shall I tell you, how much both Elizabeth and myself enjoyed being at your house.
I owe you a good deal that I shall never get paid back.
It just happens that there are very few people in the world to whom Elizabeth and I can go and in whose presence we can frankly accept each other as a man and woman who love.
Your own and Jerry's free acceptance was very sweet to both of us.  I've been pretty starved for this woman, for a long time - I mean for her in just the healthy atmosphere you two give off.
Lucile dear, I've been pretty mixed up.  I've helped mix others.  Don't quit loving me and I've a notion I'll come out all right yet.
Sherwood.
And dear, I know you and Jerry will never get into the stressed state I was long in and into which I perhaps unconsciously tried to drag others.

My dear Lucile,
It is the morning of July 1st.  I went over the the Overland Hotel and found your letter. It had been there several days perhaps.  They neglected to send it to my present address 33 E Liberty St. We had cold weather here until 10 days ago - now it is dry and hot.

For 25 days we have had evening walks every day and I haunt the tracks.  Horses and negroes seem to be the two things in America that give me the most ascetic pleasure.  A flatnosed tobacco chewing man is trading? a thoroughbred.  In the house what a noble bearing.  No lousy inferiority complex here.  The small peaceful head is thrown back. The legs are clean? and hard, the breast is strong.  All the flesh of the body quivers with desire to run.  We

2
pay something dear woman for our silly minds, don't we - always wanting to be great not daring to just even the sands out, and let her ride.

There is an amazing good library here and I read as I haven't for years.  Tried to paint but got only one clean fine thing out of about 20.  Think my nerves were pretty much shattered when I came and I hadn't enough energy for writing and painting both.  
Many Marriages did pretty well but the dealers got scared of it.  You know I had a little flare of success last year.  I think it is over.  The magazines are scared of me again aside from the financial thing its better. ?
If I have luck here and get what I'm after E & I

3
will probable go south in the fall, probable to Mobile, or New New Orleans.  I do want to try to paint a little, but there is this book to finish and a novel eating at me.  I'm going to pretty much stay away from Chicago and New York.  Whether I'm any good or not what I want is to work.  The eternal quibbling about the purposes of art, its drift etc gets on my nerves, knocks me flat.

 Maybe you and Jerry will both come back to the American negroes in the end.  The plan of putting the negroes on the stage, making him paint sing etc etc is all nonsense.  What he has to give is rather noble but is physical - like the running horse or dog, I'm pretty sure of that.

4
The thing now - for the painter is very elusive but there is something new too. Golden? color - a bright flirting thing.  If the deserts and mountains ever produce artist they will be telling of delicate - half mystic fairy tales.  The same influences that produced Egyptian art perhaps but pretty foreign to an American. There should really be all asectic marks in the holes in the mountains at the desert's edge. A strange land. Some day I'll tell you two more about it.

The indians are something too, rather hasten in their dieing? than the anglo saxon in their victory.

5

 E? is well. She makes me always happy to be in her presence. I love her as I have no one else.

It is rather odd how little influence any of my other women have had on me.

 I think I'm going to get well, ?nn afraid. I won't do what I want. God I want a lot, in work,

but I'm going to  keep at it, keep going after it.

 We'll meet again. Jerry will get into his swing,and so will you.  It's hell for us Americans to get some

smac?, isn't it.

 All my love
    Sherwood

Dear Charles,
My thoughts have turned to you a lot, these days.  My feeling, I think, is half that of a father to  a son, have pure feeling of companionship, as brother.
It may be you will escape the dark valley I have been in, that I am walking in now.  I have had to fight for and defend the artist in myself.
Once Jack Dempsey said a marvelous thing to me.  We were both at a photographers.  He walked in his quick, nervous half brutal way across the room and grabbed my shoulder. "Were you ever a fighter?"

2
he said - "you have the shoulders, the frame of a fighter.

  "No," I said, and then I thought "yes I am a fighter," I said.
  It was just before he fought Tunney.  "It is worse winning than losing", he said.

The curse of victory, fought for.  You walk over the scene and see the dead and wounded,  There are groans and people weep.
I have hurt so many people Charles - trying to keep some integrity.

3
Do I dare go on existing. A few tales, told at last. to push something out a little beyond the horizon - no one caring much.
The painter fighting, just for ground on which his easel may stand, the writer for his quiet room, his thoughts word fitted against word as salves.

I take you very close to myself because I feel in you brotherhood in it - whatever it is.

S.A.

1929?
Dear Charles -

 I have got another sale made. Am very sure I soon get three or four more.  This is to Mr

Burton Emmett - a rich Jenind?

 I came home - sad - made sad by the house, haunted by E with whom I failed.
  Nates? ol ranch? I keep thinking also of poor E's difficulties - and the impossibility of helping.

I am sending Katherine a little wood cut I liked.

 Lots of love to you both.
  Sherwood A.

1929
Charles - The more I think of it the more anxious am I to have you come sooner 
here for a time of painting. I wish I could write something very successfully
quickly so I could send you any money needed for a bit more  lisness?

 Perhaps I will.
I wish you could get to feel about money as a thing unimportant -

except when it can be applied so:

 This was a gift - Clear light over the hills on Sunday afternoon.  M

can tell you how wonderful it is sometimes.  The light such as you see in Corot.

 The solid forms are so marvelous here - all firm and lusious, like naked women,

large and firm lying asleep everywhere. I never have

3
seen such a country - nature so rich and full of mith?

 It might be too much for you at first.
 I'll come back and see you before the winter is over.
  I am going to try to go to work. I seem rich to myself. We'll see.
Lots of love to K

1929
Dear Charles and Kath

 I wrote Terence to send your Vanity Fair. He was delighted with

the little story. Alas, you see how I make the mill grind your
yamin?.  I shall, I am afraid capitalize more of your dear selves.

 I shall send Part

2
of New York in a day or two.

 S.A.

1929?   (Owned by J R Copenhaver) 
Dear Charles - The painting - "bottles and apples" is very living. I needed it. It is in my room, over the desk where I work.
The other, "trees" is in the print shop, over the folding machine.  I have the Cezanne in the room upstairs with "bottles
and apples".  It stands up - I mean your ovr? painting, in this distinguished company.

 You know the one with the grapes. Please varnish this for shipment. I have a chance to sell it for $250.00 to a rich

merchant here. If I succeed put it in a gold frame before shipping. The thing may not come off but, on the other hand
it may. I think it would be better to dispose of a few this way than to fasr? with a show, for the next few years.
Let the show come

2
two or three years from now.

 I remember so sharply my own experience - all such assiads? that one you saw and be and at the

packing place, mulling over your work, pouring over it, patronizing you.

 "Pretty good for a young man" etc
 "He has good color? but cannot draw."
 "If he could only paint"
In time you get hardened to it of course but it is a tad time.

 I have been thinking of Kath almost constantly these last few days, loving her a lot.

3

 Of course I was just playing with the story you and Kath told. It happens that way.

You jump off from Kath and have Helen. Hell Helen is not Kath. You understand.

 Often you would write a sentence. Let us suppose I start with Mary.
 I write "She was a slender woman with red hair."
  Now where has Mary gone. This red haired woman is not her.
 It is like a new color, introduced into a painting.
   I shall be in New York

4
between the 15 & 20th of March.

 If the picture sale should happen to come off I'll wire.

It is worth the gamble of Varnishing.

  Lots of love.

Dear Charles & Kath

 First $300 in. I am sending my check - thought maybe checks would

gather ?main mikman? in this, for the time.

Third from Otto Kahn. I am send a copy his delightful letter midosd?.
 Both your letters made me happy.
     Sherwood.

on side  August 1929
on top  Marion
Dear Charles - I think of you going out to paint every day. Fall coming on and then winter - the changing scene. Now
that I have got these few things of yours away here I am quite sure your determination to let yourself go -
toward color - in light.

 There was a young man here who has spent the summer in Paris. He saw your things on the wall. He lives in

Philadelphia. The other day he was talking to me. He said that, having been with your things here he felt new
strength and delicacy in your color than in any of the things seen over there by the younger men about whom a 
fuss is being made.

 He began talking about wanting to get one of your things. I told him I thought he might have one of the oils for

$50.00.  I am pretty sure the thing to do is to get a few, scattered around.

 He expressed that it might be well to let you make the

2
selection. He did not think he would have the money before about December.

 He likes the oils but wanted a small one if possible. This because he may have to live in 
restricted quarters, a small room I dare say.
 His people have money but he has none yet. If you think best I will send your address and you select one to

send to him.

 There are so few houses in which paintings may be hung. I took the green water color to a colonial house here.

It is full of antique furniture. Well I hung it on the wall. I couldn't bear it there after a week. It was like a nice
country boy with curly hair and clean blue

3
upes?, say in a ?ang of New York literary men.  I woke up in the night, thinking of it up there, and went and
got it the next morning.

 Now it is over my desk, being just right. I shall take it to Washington with me.
 You wont get things like that every day, or every week, don't expect to. I'll let it go some day, to one of the men?, or

the $300 thing or I'll sell it for $300_ not less.

 And I will have to know who gets it. There may be some opportunities in Washington.
 John m?ais he will be here Tuesday of next week. I'll write often we have talked and I know more of his plans.
 It is so hard to keep any dignity in every day life.

at top  1929  over
Charles

 Katharine wrote me about you and the Van Gogh books. I hope you will keep them a long time.

It is an annoying story.

 I think that in Renoir and Van Gogh you get the two things of which you once wrote me  - the

man going toward God and the man going down into earth and finding God there too. Perhaps I
think Renoir the healthies man.

 The terrible thing about most of the God men? is that they seem to identify themselves with God. "I

am myself this thing."  Van Gogh escaped all that - A terrible humbleness saved him.

 A thing apparently Van Go - crossed out Renoir never had at all.
 Both sevect? men though.
 I have been working hard. I hope to see you soon.

A fine Christmas to you

    S.A.

2

   his house, very quietly and eloquently furnished. I went in there and had te.  The rich collections with paints. 

How paintings have a kind of quality too although they are little little girls, all the wonders of womanhood ahead.

 In this case, the woman being say 37 - well you see.
 We talked gentle and nicely. There were paintings everywhere. At my back was a Carot figure, finely finished

and fat, a Coerbet landscape

 We were served tea very quietly and elegantly. you felt " We are ever swore in here, said God I am

shit etc."  Not that that is so necessary.

  Then we went to the galleries  All this owned by one man.   Of course he is nice, let people in.

I don't know what you can? do.  If you have a civilization where one man has

3
ten, fifteen, or fifty, while some artist hasn't a cent.

 It has always been like this though. I should think they could 

smell themselves stinking.  I guess maybe they do.  This must be
why they buy paintings, to make the smell greater in houses.

 There was a glorious Renoir the richest I have ever seen - rich

like heady wine.

 The Phydrns? were in finality tenden?. You should both see [[maes

Phydras?]]. They are hard to see.

 There were some Bareards? too. They have quality. You felt bells

ennging? in them.

 Of course I realized - no use saying anything to him. He wouldn't ni  pently sen?

buy anything less than a $1000.

 Some habn? would have to take up a man, or sti? would

4
have to be made.

 It was interesting that he had quite a lot of Maurer - that resulting from a stir I made

about Maurer several years ago.

 It depend on money coming in whether or not I shall stay here.
 You tell John I'll be ?anting? him. Really the ? are no good. They are ugly, even

when they are beautiful paintings. It's a puzzle.

I think it would be a great mistake to waste any time at all,

thinking of form, as form.  It is one of the things artists, and most of all half artists, babble
of when their minds are most vacant.

 Form is of canest? content. It is nothing else, can be nothing else. A tree has bark, fiber, sap, leaves, limbs, twigs.
 It can  perdes? and exist and not grow in the soil of your own being.  It is so with women too.

The great thing is to let yourself be the tree, the sky, the earth. Enter in to your inheritance. It is difficult and can only
happen auely?, as between a man and a woman.

2

My meaning is that life is not so separated from art. How often I go away from the

presence of talking artists into the street the field.

 What I want is there. If I go in and come out alive?, ever now and then, in the end these same 

people who say I have no form will be prattling at the "form" in my work.

 I'll see you soon.
   S.A.

1930
Dear Charles.

 I will send the Lady Chatterly today. I think it a revolutionary book - perhaps the great book

of our times.

 The painting came. I got the big one, jugs, bottles and apples in the gold frame in which I had the other

large still life.

 The pot with flowers I'm having framed.  I have sent the large still life - bottles, the blue clothes? and apples

on the table To

2
Maurice Lang - of Washington. who is to put in $100 in the pot.

 These new things have something beyond what you have had before.

There is an increased quiet elegance and strength. The color glows.
It is more subtle, and stronger.   You always need Clin? Charles. 
I never knew a painter with

3
less dirt in him. It is a constant joy to see that this is so.

 Sometime ago you said something about art needing joy.

You are getting it.

 I shall pass on to Miss Copenhaver either the green trees

or the little blocked in native cedar? that is so lovely

 All of these things will be where they can

4
be had for a show later, when the time comes for the one man show.

 I think Charles that, in going to Bel-Air, which I suppose is the last

thing now, you should feel yourself a man and a painter. You have
so proven that. Take what you want. Do not let the intensity of the
family life

5
intrude. I've a feeling that perhaps you and Mr Persy?
may get at each other a little. It could be worth trying for.

 I have the large self portrait John did of himself. It wants joy in nature - the

thing you have - but it has fine paint quality and stands up beautifully

 You have sure made

6
my work come? live again.

 Don't have any fear of the future Charles.

We'll sure pull it off some way. It is
miraclous? to me that you have escaped just that
damn fool thing in painting the Msslanany? and
are indulging in in prose.

 Love  Sherwood

I have a great desire to see you do some people. It would

be wonderful if you could get rite a few  portraits the same jars in oiles

page out of order
2
in a pretty deep valley with Tanen wally? on all sides of me. It has seemed at times that all people
I loved and who loved me were immeasurably far away.  It was as though you had gone away, over some
deep ocean and my voice could not reach you.

 Now it seems to me I am a little coming up to the surface again.
 It is partly the thing that I hope you Charles may avoid. But how can it be avoided. A man

publishes a book or hangs a picture. He does it with some humility but such mean motives are attributed to
him, there is such a wallowing that he ends up by feeling dirty, dirty, dirty.

 For some reason I seem to be a person about whom a controversy must always go on. with every

new book I feel this invasion. Perhaps painters never quite have to go through that.

 You are right about the town and the country here. Temporarily,

Dear Charles.

 I am at home again. I drove up through Alabama and the Carolinas waiting? for

you & John. My dates in Chicago - to lecture art there are from April 22 into early May. 
I dont know yet whether John will want to come that early. I have written him to ask.

 I have had good days and bad days. I keep going. Now I am working away at the

speeches, feeling that, as long as I am in it I should give the best I have.

 It will be rather fun, I hope - or time of a kind of debauch as pro?h  I fell fairly strong for it.
 I am anxious about your show - not so much for its ? cinn? but out of fear that you may have to

go through a bad time. The vulgar and the cheap we have been always with us.

 Anyway Charles we have yet to hang onto our faith in our

2
own way. The inner coauld in which we at last try to reach is as ena?l as their world.

I wish I could say - "set fire to the houses."  I cant of course. We have to try to keep

the quee talanes? between deprecation and their damn swaywss fone? way.

 The best I know is the fact, for me that men like you exist.  That others are in the game ? too.

Its the only thing to hold onto I know about.

 Sherwood

Friday    1930  over

My Dear Charles -
 I am up early - shortly after six - a cold frosty morning. I have been working in the streets. Last night, at 2 in

the morning, a man called me, on the long distance phone from a plantation, far down in Louisiana.

 He was drunk - had read something of mine that had stirred him. When he got drunk he wanted to talk to me - He

was strangely incoherent and profane about life. It was a queer uncanny experience.

 When I see you I will tell you about him.
 I am leaving for Chicago - to speak out there - never in my life having been las? in the word.
 I am looking forward to the rearrangement of my life here and to another kind of life later on. It is going to be a hard

few months ahead.

 You all know how I wanted to see you - what it would have meant to me. This summer, if you do achieve

some freedom, I will come and be near you.  My love to you and Katharine.

  Sherwood

letterhead    New Walton, De Funiak Springs. Fla.                   Cherokee, Tallahasse, Fla.                      Harbeson Hotel, Camp Walton, Fla.

                                                            SAN CARLOS HOTEL
                                                        W.B. Harbeson, Proprietor
                                                         L.C. Hagler, Manager

Dear Charles -

 I am way down here on the coast. I get these terrible restless times - so I drift. It

seems to help a little. I was, for several days in the Carolinas and in Georgia.
Now I am going on to New Orleans and thru Asive?.

 In the Carolinas and Georgia all the soil is red and yellow. There are yenab? fields

all blood red. The pine trees all go straight up, as though reaching for something.
The roads are always clean.

 They wound the pine trees to get turpentine,

letterhead text New Walton, De Funiak Springs, Fla.   Cherokee, Tallahasse, Fla.    Harbeson Hotel, Camp Walton, Fla.
SAN CARLOS HOTEL
W. B. Harbeson, Proprietor. L.C. Hagler, Manager. Pensacola, Florida.
end of letterhead text
2
making great ghashes in the trunks. It hurts  you to see them.
The esads? are maeacluses? They seem painted, rather than real.
About Mereau? there are thousands of acres of ?aches They all burst into blossom while I was there.  
The whole landscape suddenly got that light floating quality you get in Chinese painting.
The people are miserably poor.  Yesterday I was all day in yellow sand woods.  As you get closer

letterhead text  New Walton, De Funiak Springs, Fla.    Cherokee, Tallahasse, Fla.     Harbeson Hotel, Camp Walton, Fla.
SAN CARLOS HOTEL
W. B. Harbeson, Proprietor. L.C. Hagler, Manager. Pensacola, Florida.
end of letterhead text
3
toward the coast it is all like a  nce? bottom.
People live in qualar sic - squalor, in misery.
Only the negroes are nice.  They go seemlessly along, finely built men and women. You see women
with great loads talanad? on their heads, fine broad-hipped women .

It is that upper and middle swath, Georgia and the Carolinas that is gorgeous for color

Love,
S.A.

1930? over
Dear John and Charles,
There is a tickllish point that I am trying to get at.  I have a notion you may arrive at it in various ways, you try this and try that.

What happens to you in the world of painting happens in prose too.
You say "everything is in color, in keeping all loose, let form grow out of color."

We say, "everything is in feeling. Let yourself feel dance?  and dance? into lives."

 It is all right but there is a kind of insanity in it too.  You can't let yourself be quite loose. 
 As a prose writer and that is to say, "as a man who pretends to depict human life", I have you as far

I suppose as a man can go on the road of feeling.  I have wrecked myself time and again.
It is all involved in sex. I think my generation went

2
a little nuts on that, myself with them.  We rather centered all feeling in sex.

We got insults , did a kind of work , I dare say, I know I have done a few beautiful tales.
You see there was the easier times of the Puritans.  You, Charles and Kath know about that.

Just because they had power they were overplayed, given a position of too much importance.

Their power over the residual men is really gone, I think

We have got new people growing  up who will never know the inhibitions against which we fought.

 You see I am like the painter who having gone to color and then to color and then to color turns suddenly

again to live - the thing Charles spoke of in his letter.

3
I have imagined a man who has taken color as sex. Do you see?    It is an attempt to return into the
pagan world.

 But this isn't a pagan world. It is a world of machines.
 When I called what I am trying to do "No God", I meant only that old gods are dead.
You have to find in your way new centers of relationships. 

I for example have to come, for the time at least, out of a world where I depend on feeling (color) and have to begin
again to observe with my eyes, hear with my ears the definate facts.

  It is the same thing you mean when you go back to drawing.
  You say to these inner voices "be still now for a time,"
  I imagine our whole

4
lives must be spent in this kind of going back and forth.

 We gather what we can and retire with it, try to let it do something inside of us, to us,

like Keck, having become inpregnated.

 Of course it is terribly confusing working, as we writers must, in lives.  But after all

not more surprising than your difficulties. I understand that.

 I think the gods are there but they are far off just now.
 The thing about which you spoke was sold to Scribners, I'll send it when printed.
   Last week I did a short thing for Vanity Fair, almost devoid of color, almost pure drawing. 

I called it These Mountains, just a description of your people, all my own feeling aftart?.
I think it was good.

  Love to All
   Sherwood

July 1930
Dear Charles.

 I am writing from Marion - where I have gone to ? the papers for a few days, to let Bob off.
 Surely, will send the $100 before Aug 1st. Came as early in Aug as possible, not of course

to kill anything you have started there.

 I think this - that it is a fight against ugliness - in ourselves and others. Often? we lose the fight.

My living is terribly stormy some times.

 It is lonely enough in life, God knows - without the few men of our own times who feel as we do, 

some where about - its too lonely

As I have told you, dear Charles, all of this means a lot to Bob, John and I.

 I have a scheme to get the 1st hundred that will ? you. When it is worked out

will write you

 Tell Kack that John is waiting and will send a more intelligent floor plan of the house.

John and I were talking it over. The house will be charming when K has been at it a week. You
will come at? first nite my house while you work it out.

3

There are any number of things I haven't mentioned to Kack.
 For example she must grease the pig with kerosene - to prevent lice.

This is wonderful for the hands.    

  Then there is the care to be taken to the bull.

That is a task. She goes a bit crazy, darbe?    Through ? etc.  Hanging onto
her does something wonderful to the ankles.

 There are other things for the development of the female figure. I may make a list for Kack.

4
handy I'm glad. It will make the whole place so much more alive and
worth while for all of us too.

 Love to you both.
   S.A.
